content.text: To define the standards of pedagogical excellence expected in all Eduversal Partner Schools, ensuring that instruction is student-centered, evidence-based, and aligned with Cambridge and national curriculum requirements.
The ETS framework outlines the core competencies required of all teachers. It serves as the basis for recruitment, professional development, and appraisal.

items.title: Standard 1: Professional Knowledge
points: Understands how students learn and develop.
Knows the curriculum frameworks (Cambridge & National) thoroughly.

items.title: Standard 2: Instructional Planning
points: Plans lessons that are clear, logical, and aligned to learning objectives.
Incorporates differentiation to meet diverse learner needs.

items.title: Standard 3: Instructional Delivery
points: Uses a variety of active learning strategies.

items.title: Standard 4: Assessment for Learning
points: Uses formative assessment to check understanding during lessons.
Adjusts instruction based on assessment results.

items.title: Standard 5: Learning Environment
points: Creates a safe, inclusive, and positive classroom culture.
Manages student behavior effectively and respectfully.

items.title: Standard 6: Professionalism
points: Engages in continuous professional reflection and growth.
Upholds ethical standards and school policies.

content.text: Eduversal schools prioritize 'Active Learning' as defined by Cambridge International Education. Students are not passive recipients of knowledge but active participants in constructing meaning.

content.title: Key Strategies
items: Inquiry-Based Learning: Starting with questions, problems, or scenarios.
Collaborative Learning: Pair work, group projects, peer teaching.
Metacognition: Helping students think about their own thinking and learning processes.
Differentiation: Tailoring instruction to meet individual needs (see Section 5.9).

content.text: Teachers should aim for a ratio where student talk/activity exceeds teacher talk time in the majority of lessons.
Effective teaching begins with intentional planning. All teachers are required to maintain up-to-date lesson plans.

content.title: Lesson Plan Components
rows: Specific, measurable goals derived from the curriculum (e.g., 'Students will be able to analyze...').
How students will know they have achieved the objective.
Activity to engage students and activate prior knowledge.
Sequence of learning tasks, including teacher modeling, guided practice, and independent practice.
Review of learning and check for understanding.
Specific adaptations for EAL, SEN, or gifted students.

content.text: A positive learning environment is a prerequisite for academic success.

items: Physical Environment: Classrooms should be clean, organized, and display student work and learning aids.
Emotional Safety: Students must feel safe to take risks, make mistakes, and express their ideas.
Routines and Procedures: Clear expectations for transitions, handing in work, and asking for help maximize learning time.

content.text: Eduversal is committed to the continuous growth of its teaching staff.
Teaching quality is monitored through a supportive and developmental process.

items: Lesson Observations: Formal (announced) and informal (walkthrough) observations by leadership.
Work Scrutiny: Regular review of student notebooks and assignments to check for feedback quality and marking.
Student Feedback: Surveys regarding teaching effectiveness and engagement.

content.label: Cross-Reference
content.text: Detailed appraisal procedures are outlined in Section 12 (Staff Lifecycle) and Section 17 (Quality Assurance).
